subject: polity
title: Legislative Assembly vs Legislative Council - State Legislature Comparison
description: Comprehensive comparison of State Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha) and Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad) covering constitutional provisions, composition, powers, and procedures

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Art 170**: Constitution of Legislative Assembly
**Lower House** of State Legislature
Directly represents **People** of State
rows.legislative_council:
**Art 169**: Abolition/Creation of Legislative Council
**Upper House** of State Legislature
Represents **diverse sections** of society

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Mandatory** in every State
**Cannot be abolished**
Every State must have an Assembly
rows.legislative_council:
**Optional** - At State's discretion
Can be **created or abolished** by Parliament (Art 169)
**Special majority** of Assembly + Parliament approval needed

rows.legislative_assembly:
**All 28 States** have Legislative Assembly
**All States** mandatory
rows.legislative_council:
**Only 6 States** currently have Council:
• **Andhra Pradesh** (68 members)
• **Telangana** (40 members)
• **Karnataka** (75 members)
• **Maharashtra** (78 members)
• **Bihar** (75 members)
• **Uttar Pradesh** (100 members - highest)

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Temporary body** - Dissolves after 5 years
**Entire House** dissolves at once
Can be dissolved before 5 years by Governor
rows.legislative_council:
**Permanent body** - Never dissolves
**1/3rd members retire** every 2 years
Continuous existence like Rajya Sabha

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Direct election** by people
**FPTP (First Past The Post)** system
One member per constituency
rows.legislative_council:
**6 categories of members** (Art 171(3)):
• 1/3rd by Local Bodies
• 1/3rd by Assembly members
• 1/12th by Teachers (3+ years)
• 1/12th by Graduates (3+ years)
• 1/6th nominated by Governor

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Max 500 members** (Art 170(1))
**Min 60 members** (exception: smaller states)
• Mizoram, Goa, Sikkim: 40 members (min)
• Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland: 60 members
• UP: 403 members (highest currently)
rows.legislative_council:
**Max: 1/3rd of Assembly strength** (Art 171(1))
**Min: 40 members**
• UP: 100 members (highest)
• Telangana: 40 members (lowest)
Cannot exceed 1/3rd of Assembly

rows.legislative_assembly:
**1 Anglo-Indian** nominated by Governor (if needed)
**Lapsed** after 104th Amendment 2020
No other nominated members
rows.legislative_council:
**1/6th members** nominated by Governor (Art 171(3)(e))
Experts in: **Literature, Science, Art, Cooperative movement, Social service**
About 7-17 members depending on State

rows.legislative_assembly:
**5 years** normal term (Art 172(1))
Can be dissolved earlier by Governor
**Emergency**: Extended by 1 year at a time (max 1 year after Emergency ends)
rows.legislative_council:
**6 years** term for each member (Art 172(1))
**1/3rd retire** every 2 years (about 13-33 members)
Member can be re-elected indefinitely

rows.legislative_assembly:
• Indian citizen
• **25+ years** of age
• No office of profit
• Registered voter in State
rows.legislative_council:
• Indian citizen
• **30+ years** of age
• No office of profit
• Registered voter in State

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Speaker** (Art 178)
Elected by Assembly members from amongst themselves
Usually from ruling party
Cannot vote except in tie (casting vote)
rows.legislative_council:
**Chairman** (Art 182)
Elected by Council members from amongst themselves
Cannot vote except in tie (casting vote)
Similar to RS Chairman

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Deputy Speaker** (Art 178)
Elected by Assembly members
Usually from opposition (convention)
Removable by effective majority
rows.legislative_council:
**Deputy Chairman** (Art 182)
Elected by Council members
Removable by effective majority
Presides when Chairman absent

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Speaker & Deputy Speaker** removable by:
• Resolution of Assembly
• Effective majority (simple majority)
• **14 days notice** required (Art 179)
Rarely happens
rows.legislative_council:
**Chairman & Deputy Chairman** removable by:
• Resolution of Council
• Effective majority (simple majority)
• **14 days notice** required (Art 183)
Rarely happens

rows.legislative_assembly:
**SC & ST seats** reserved (Art 170(1))
Based on population of SC/ST in State
Example: UP has 85 SC + 2 ST reserved seats
rows.legislative_council:
**No reservation** for SC/ST
All members through election/nomination
No caste-based reservation

rows.legislative_assembly:
**1/10th of total strength** or 10 members (whichever is more)
If no quorum, meeting adjourned
Often misused to stall proceedings
rows.legislative_council:
**1/10th of total strength** or 10 members (whichever is more)
If no quorum, meeting adjourned
Same as Assembly

rows.legislative_assembly:
Can initiate **ANY bill** including Money Bills
**Final authority** on all bills
If bill sent back by Council, Assembly can pass again
**Dominates** in bicameral legislature
rows.legislative_council:
Can initiate **any bill EXCEPT Money Bills**
Can delay **Ordinary Bill** by max **3-4 months** total
Can delay **Money Bill** by max **14 days**
Cannot reject bills - Assembly prevails

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Exclusive power** to originate Money Bills
**Final authority** on Money Bills
Can accept/reject Council recommendations
**Speaker's certificate** final
Council cannot delay beyond 14 days
rows.legislative_council:
**Cannot initiate** Money Bills
Can **recommend amendments** (not binding)
**14 days** to return with recommendations
If not returned in 14 days, deemed passed
**No veto power** - Similar to Rajya Sabha

rows.legislative_assembly:
Passes bill, sends to Council
If Council:
• Rejects: Assembly can pass again after 3 months
• Amends: Assembly can accept/reject
• No action for 3 months: Deemed rejected
**Assembly will prevail** ultimately
rows.legislative_council:
Can:
• Reject bill
• Amend bill
• Sit on bill for 3 months
But **cannot stop** bill - Assembly can pass again
Max delay: **3-4 months** total

rows.legislative_assembly:
Receives bill from Council
Can:
• Pass as is
• Amend
• Reject
**Final authority** on all bills
Council has no recourse if Assembly rejects
rows.legislative_council:
Can originate Ordinary Bills (NOT Money Bills)
Sends to Assembly for approval
If Assembly rejects, bill dies
**Assembly supremacy** maintained

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Exclusive power** to vote on State Budget
Votes on **Demands for Grants**
Can **reduce/reject** but **NOT increase** demand
**Cut Motions** allowed
**Full control** over State finances
rows.legislative_council:
**Cannot vote** on Budget
**Cannot vote** on Demands for Grants
Can **discuss** budget
**No control** over State finances
Similar to Rajya Sabha role

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Final authority** on Appropriation Bill
Must pass for govt to withdraw from Consolidated Fund
Council can recommend (14 days, not binding)
Cannot be amended (amounts already voted)
rows.legislative_council:
Can make **recommendations** (14 days)
Cannot reject or amend
Assembly can accept/reject recommendations
**No control** over withdrawal from State Fund

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Full control** over Council of Ministers
Council collectively responsible **ONLY to Assembly**
Can move **no-confidence motion**
If passed, govt must resign
**Real power center** of State
rows.legislative_council:
**No control** over Council of Ministers
Ministers can be from Council
Can ask questions, discuss policies
**Cannot move no-confidence** motion
**No executive control**

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Only in Assembly**
Can move no-confidence against State govt
If passed, **govt must resign**
CM must command majority in Assembly
**Most powerful tool**
rows.legislative_council:
**NOT allowed** in Council
Cannot move no-confidence
Can criticize policies but cannot remove govt
Same as Rajya Sabha

rows.legislative_assembly:
New CM must prove majority in Assembly
**Floor test** conducted in Assembly
Governor can order floor test
Decides govt stability
rows.legislative_council:
**No floor test** in Council
CM need not prove majority in Council
Council has no role in govt formation
Same pattern as Parliament

rows.legislative_assembly:
**1 hour** (timing varies by State)
Starred & Unstarred questions
Ministers must answer
More impactful due to executive responsibility
rows.legislative_council:
**1 hour** (timing varies by State)
Starred & Unstarred questions
Ministers must answer
Less impactful (no executive control)

rows.legislative_assembly:
Can move adjournment motion
Censures government
Discusses urgent public importance
Powerful tool to criticize govt
rows.legislative_council:
Can move adjournment motion
Discusses urgent matters
But cannot remove govt (no no-confidence)
Weaker impact than Assembly

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Allowed** during Demands for Grants:
• **Policy Cut** (Re 1)
• **Economy Cut** (specific amount)
• **Token Cut** (Rs 100)
Powerful opposition tool
rows.legislative_council:
**NOT allowed**
Cannot vote on Demands for Grants
Cannot move Cut Motions
No financial control

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Summoned by Governor**
Typically 3-4 sessions per year:
• Budget Session
• Monsoon/Monsoon Session
• Winter Session
Max gap: **6 months** between sessions
rows.legislative_council:
**Summoned by Governor**
Sessions coincide with Assembly sessions
Meets separately but parallel
Same 6-month gap rule

rows.legislative_assembly:
Governor prorogues Assembly (ends session)
Pending bills **do NOT lapse** (unless dissolved)
Committee work continues
rows.legislative_council:
Governor prorogues Council (ends session)
Pending bills **do NOT lapse**
Committee work continues
Never dissolves

rows.legislative_assembly:
**All pending bills lapse** (except bills in Council)
Speaker & Deputy Speaker vacate office
New elections conducted
New Assembly within 6 months
rows.legislative_council:
**Never dissolves** - Permanent body
No concept of dissolution
Bills pending in Council do NOT lapse
Continuous existence

rows.legislative_assembly:
Most ministers from Assembly (convention)
CM must command majority in Assembly
**Max 15%** of Assembly strength (91st Amendment)
Must be member within **6 months**
rows.legislative_council:
Ministers can be from Council
But CM must have Assembly support
**Max 15%** of Assembly strength (not Council)
Counts towards Assembly 15% limit

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Can abolish Council**:
• Assembly must pass resolution (Majority of total + 2/3rd present)
• Parliament passes bill (Simple majority)
• Council **cannot prevent** its own abolition
**Cannot be abolished** itself
rows.legislative_council:
**Can be abolished** by Parliament (Art 169)
**Can be created** if State Assembly requests:
• Assembly passes resolution
• Parliament passes bill
Council has **no say** in its abolition

rows.legislative_assembly:
Andhra Pradesh:
• Council abolished in 1985
• Re-created in 2007
• Abolished again in 2024
Assembly remains throughout
rows.legislative_council:
**Abolished** in several States:
• Punjab (1969)
• West Bengal, Tamil Nadu (1969)
• Andhra Pradesh (1985, 2024)
**Created**: Telangana (2020)

rows.legislative_assembly:
**No provision** for Joint Sitting of State Legislature
Unlike Parliament (Art 108)
Assembly simply passes bill again after delay
rows.legislative_council:
**No provision** for Joint Sitting
Assembly can pass bill after delay
No Joint Sitting mechanism in Constitution for States

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Presidential Election**: MLAs vote (Electoral College)
**Rajya Sabha Election**: MLAs elect RS members (STV)
**Council Election**: MLAs elect 1/3rd of Council members
rows.legislative_council:
**No role** in Presidential election (not in Electoral College)
**No role** in Rajya Sabha election
**Elects**: 1/3rd of its own members

rows.legislative_assembly:
**No power** to remove Governor
Can pass resolution requesting removal
Only President can remove Governor
Assembly has no binding power
rows.legislative_council:
**No power** to remove Governor
Can pass resolution (non-binding)
Only President removes Governor
Same as Assembly

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Only Assembly** ratifies Constitutional Amendments
50% State Assemblies needed for certain amendments
Council has **no role** in ratification
**Assembly represents State** for ratification
rows.legislative_council:
**No role** in ratifying Constitutional Amendments
Only Assembly can ratify
Council completely excluded from amendment process
**Major distinction** from Parliament

rows.legislative_assembly:
**Supreme in State**
**Can**: Control finances, Remove govt, Abolish Council, Ratify amendments
**More powerful** than Council in ALL matters
**Real power center** - Similar to Lok Sabha
rows.legislative_council:
**Much weaker** than Assembly
**Cannot**: Control finances, Remove govt, Prevent abolition, Ratify amendments
**Can**: Delay bills (3-4 months), Provide expert scrutiny
Often called **'House of Elders'** with diverse representation

rows.legislative_assembly:
• **Mandatory** in every State (cannot be abolished)
• **5-year term**, directly elected by people
• **Supreme power** over finances, executive, legislation
• CM responsible **ONLY to Assembly**
• Can **abolish Council** (Art 169)
• Ratifies Constitutional Amendments
• **Similar to Lok Sabha** at State level
rows.legislative_council:
• **Optional** - Only **6 States** have Council currently
• **6-year term**, 1/3rd retire every 2 years, **never dissolves**
• **6 categories**: 1/3rd Local Bodies, 1/3rd Assembly, 1/12th Teachers, 1/12th Graduates, 1/6th Nominated
• **Can be abolished** by Parliament (Art 169)
• Can delay Ordinary Bill **3-4 months**, Money Bill **14 days**
• **NO control** over govt (no no-confidence power)
• **Similar to Rajya Sabha** at State level

data.summary: Legislative Assembly is SUPREME in State Legislature. Assembly has exclusive control over Money Bills, Budget & Grants, and can remove government via no-confidence. Council can delay Ordinary Bills (3-4 months max) and Money Bills (14 days max) but cannot reject them. Assembly can abolish Council (Art 169) - Council cannot prevent its own abolition. Only 6 States currently have bicameral legislature: Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Bihar, Uttar Pradesh. Council has 6 categories of members (Local Bodies, Assembly members, Teachers, Graduates, Nominated). Assembly (5-year term, directly elected, 25+ age) is similar to Lok Sabha; Council (6-year term, indirectly elected/nominated, 30+ age) is similar to Rajya Sabha. Key exam point: Assembly can abolish Council, but Council CANNOT be abolished by itself. Constitutional Amendments ratified ONLY by Assembly, not Council.
